Jessica helps with housework but also raises animals like chickens and guinea pigs that she sells in her community.  She also works in farming and what she harvests is both for her own consumption and to sell.

She’s in the fifth loan with the communal bank and she will use it to buy chickens and chicken feed.  Her goal is to continue with her University classes and become a professional.  

The children in the photo are the children of some of the members.

loans.use: to buy chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, two of whom attend school.  She has no additional family members. 

Robinah has a retail shop at the market.  She also sells piped water.  She has been in business for the last seven years and works six days a week.  She has requested a loan in the amount of 600,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy sugar, rice and salt.  The two major challenges she faces in her business are transportation and price fluctuation.  Her goal is to expand into the wholesale business.  

She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and running water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: to buy sugar, salt, soap and rice.

loans.name: Falilatu

texts.en:
This is 46-year-old Falilatu.  She is married and has 2 children, aged 16 and 4 yrs. She has 2 additional dependents.  

In 2010, Falilatu established her medical services business. She began her business because she was trained as a nurse and decided to start her own business in medicine. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about Le 800,000 every month from this business. 

Falilatu would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000.   She requires a loan in order to buy more medicine in a large quantity. In the future, Falilatu plans to build her own hospital that will be managed by herself.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: buy medicine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve on business

loans.name: Kossi

texts.en:
Kossi H. is 43, monogamous, and the father of eight. He is also responsible for three others. He embraced his main business of agriculture after finishing grade school. It's a difficult way to make a living because of the rudimentary level of farming and especially because of the problem with water. Due to the rarity of rain, seven months out of twelve are months of shortages.

To solve his problems, particularly with regards to growing vegetables such as peppers and tomatoes, he often turns to renting motorized pumps. To be able to operate completely independently and with the means to do so, he is requesting a loan of $1,000 to be repaid in 12 months. The loan would be for acquiring his own motorized pump and an automatic irrigation system.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Monogame, H. Kossi, âgé de 43 ans, est père de huit (08) enfants et de trois (03) autres personnes à sa charge. Il a pour activité principale l’agriculture qu’il a embrassée après ses études primaires. Ce métier est très difficile pour son caractère rudimentaire et surtout à cause du problème d’eau. Sept mois sur douze sont des mois de soudure à cause de la rareté de la pluie en ces périodes.

Pour s’en sortir surtout avec la culture des légumineuses tels que les piments et les tomates, il a souvent recours à la location des motos pompes. Pour travailler en toute indépendance et avec plus de moyens, il sollicite aujourd’hui un crédit de $1000 à rembourser en 12 mois pour s’acheter une moto pompe et un système d’arrosage automatique.

loans.use: To buy a motorized pump and an automatic irrigation system

loans.name: Leonidas

texts.en:
Leonidas es un campesino de Baba, un sector de Ecuador donde predomina la producción del arroz. El esta solicitando un prestamo para poder invertir en los productos necesarios para sembrar, como las semillas y el fertilizante. El tiene 6 hijos, uno de los cuales todavía lo esta apoyando en sus estudios. El resto también son arroceros, e inclusivo hay varios que lo ayudan a el en sus tierras. Leonida espera mejorar su vivienda con el prestamo, ya que ahora es de madera y es bien vulnerable a las lluvias fuertes que frecuentan el sector.

English:

Translated by Nuria Ruiz, Kiva Voluteer.

Leonidas is a peasant from Baba, a region of Ecuador where the main source of income is the cultivation of rice. He is requesting a loan to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Leonidas has six children , one of which is still studing. The rest of his kids are also rice laborers, some of them help him with the land. Leaonidas plans to also use some of the loan money to do some improvements on his house. His home is made of wood and thus not fitted for the rainy season.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Rosa de Oro (Golden Rose) Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Rosa de Oro helps the farmers by providing access to machinery, training services and government assistance. The farmers from Rosa de Oro are very close to each other and cooperate to help one another on their farms.

The members of Rosa de Oro will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Rosa de Oro Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Invertir en arroz en su finca

loans.name: Ry

texts.en: Mrs. Ry P. is a 36-year-old housewife who takes care of her husband and 6 children in Siem Reap.  Her husband works as a construction foreman and earns about $5/day in this business.  Her six children are still students, although some of them work selling souvenirs around Angkor Wat after school.  Currently, Mrs. Ry P. pays motorbike taxis to take her husband and children to and from work and school.  She will use this loan to purchase a motorbike so she can take them each day, saving the family money in the long term.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to transport her family to and from work.

loans.name: Lorena Guadalupe

texts.es:
Lorena is 31 years old and has one child. Her husband works as an accountant in the local social security office. To contribute to the family bills, Lorena has a small grocery shop in her house, which allows her to work while being able to care for the home and the children. She is part of a group called Genesys 1, together with Delia Jesus T., (who also has a grocery shop). With the loan, they would like to buy merchandise to improve their shops.

LORENA, tiene 31 años, 1 hijo, su esposo labora como contador en el seguro social de su localidad. Ella para contribuir al gasto familiar tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su casa de esta forma pude ganarse la vida trabajando sin descuidar las atenciones del hogar.. Pertenece al grupo Génesis 1 junto con doña Delia Jesús T. (tienda de abarrotes) Con el préstamo esperan comprar mercadería para abastecer sus locales

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: grocery shop

loans.name: Ivonne

texts.es:
Ivonne is 35 years old and is the mother of three children. She worked for a company but they terminated her position for gender-based reasons. Since then, she has decided to own her own business. For this purpose, she needed financing, but no institution wanted to lend her capital. Only Manuela Ramos had faith in her. That's why, together with her husband, she was able to buy a small piece of land and decided to plant camu camu (a fruit of the zone).

With the recent loan (approximately US$333.00) given by Manuela Ramos that will be repaid in five months, she will buy two sacks of seeds, set up two nurseries, and maintain the land.

She is very happy to depend on her business and, despite the fact that most of the work in the region is done by males, she can demonstrate that women are also capable.

Now, with her husband, she is germinating camu camu seeds to start planting.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Sheaffer, Princeton University Language Project volunteer.

La señora Ivonne al Banco Comunal Las Lomas de Yarina, del Jr Octavio Monteverde Nro. 153 el Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 35 años y es madre de 3 hijos. Trabajó en una empresa donde por razones de genero decidieron sacarla, desde ese entonces decide tener un negocio propio, para ello necesitaba financiamiento, ninguna institución le quiso prestar dinero para capital, solo Manuela Ramos confíó en ella, por eso conjuntamente con su esposo compraron un pequeño terreno y decidieron sembrar camu camu (fruta de la zona) Con el reciente préstamo otorgado por Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,000 (US$ 333.00 aprox.), que cancelará en 5 meses, comprará 2 sacos de semillas, instalar 2 almácigos y dará manteniendo al terreno. Ella esta muy contenta de depender de su negocio y a pesar que este trabajo en la Región, en su mayoría, es realizado por varones, ella puede demostrar que también las mujeres pueden. Ahora conjuntamente con su esposo realizan todo el proceso de germinación del camu camu terminando en las plantaciones.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and land maintenance.

loans.name: Karla Evelyn

texts.es:
Karla Evelin began the business of selling footwear in order to help her mother. After a while she saw that her mother made good profits, and told her mother that if she could have some of the goods, Karla would pay her what was gained from the sales . This is how her mother decided to help start Karla's business, which Karla runs and which helps provide the income needed so tha she can continue studying.

But school costs are high, so they are asking for a loan of $ 925 USD, which she is willing to pay within a period of 6 months. With this money, she'll be able to buy more goods at wholesale prices, and get material to build a space solely for the sale of shoes to her clients.

With your help Karla can move forward and finish her career.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Karla Evelin comenzó el negocio de venta de calzado ayudándole a su mamá, después de un tiempo vio que su mamá tenia buenos ingresos y le dijo a su mamá que si le podía surtir mercancía y posteriormente Karla le pagaba de lo que fuera ganando de las ventas. Fue así como la mamá decidió ayudarla a comenzar el negocio que actualmente maneja Karla y que le ayuda a sacar dinero para poder seguir estudiando.

Sin embargo los gastos que tiene en la escuela son mucho por lo tanto necesita un crédito de US $925 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero poder comprar más mercancía a precio de mayoreo y así tener material para poder poner un local para que sus clientas puedan buscarla en un lugar establecido. Con tu ayuda Karla podrá salir adelante y terminar su carrera.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.  (Comprar mercancía)

loans.name: Juan Angel

texts.es:
Mr. Juan Ángel Rodríguez Villalba is 51 years of age, married, and has 2 grown up children.

Juan used to work in a cotton company in Ybycui, but after many years working there, he decided to leave it. With his severance pay, he was able to buy tools to open an automotive repair shop. Since then, he has dedicated his time and effort to his business with great sacrifice.

He is able to cover the household expenses with the profits earned from his business, which is vital because his wife is a homemaker and therefore does not receive any income.

He will use the loan to buy tools for his automotive repair shop.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El Señor Juan Ángel Rodríguez Villalba tiene 51 años de edad, es casado y tiene 2 hijos, ambos mayores de edad.

Juan trabajaba en la algodonera Ybycui, luego de muchos años decidió salir de la empresa y como fue bien indemnizado, con ese dinero compro herramientas para abrir un taller mecánico de automóviles, actividad a la que se dedica desde ese entonces con mucho sacrificio.

Con las ganancias que obtiene de su taller, solventa los gastos de la casa, ya que su esposa no trabaja y solo se dedica a los quehaceres domésticos.

El crédito será destinado a la compra de herramientas para su taller.

loans.use: Purchase of new tools for his automotive repair shop

loans.name: Dinh Tinh

texts.vi:
Mr. Tính, 30 years old, is a skillful carpenter of his village. He has quite a lot of commissions due to his studious nature and fine workmanship. He builds his shop by borrowing money from relatives. The loans are almost paid off. He would like to apply for a loan of 150USD from Binh Minh to buy equipment.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Anh Tính, 30 tuôi, là một thợ mộc lành nghề nổi tiếng trong thôn. Là người cần cũ lại khéo tay hay làm nên anh được nhiều chủ xưởng thuê. Mong muốn có thể tự mình gây dựng được cơ nghiệp, anh đã đi vay vốn của họ hàng nhưng đã trả gần hết. Giờ, anh thích vay theo chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì thủ tục ở đây đơn giản lại thuận tiện. Số tiền 2006000đ anh dùng để mua máy làm nghề mộc.

loans.use: Buy woodworking tools

loans.name: Ada

texts.es:
Mrs. Ada M. R. is a member of the communal bank “Santa Rosa de Lima.” She lives in the region of San Martín in the province of Huallaga and the district of Bellavista. The business is located in her house at Jiron Bolivar #155. Her store sells general grocery items, candies, and other edible products for daily consumption. She complements her other business by selling beauty products, such as Avon, Unique, and Ebel, which she keeps in stock, as well as purchasing other brands on request.

With a loan of S/.3,000 (approximately $1,050 US), which she will repay in 6 months, Ada will buy rice, sacks of sugar, milk, oil, boxes of canned fish, eggs, and sweets. She will also buy large quantities of beauty products to make the most of seasonal deals and thus be fully supplied and fill the orders of her strong clientele, which she has developed thanks to her excellent service and perseverance in the industry.

Ada is 58 years old and lives with her husband and 3 children. She is very grateful to the communal bank for providing her with the opportunity to gain capital and to develop her own small business.

Translated from Spanish by Thomas Daw, Andrew Kirsch, and Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteers.

La señora Ada es socia del banco comunal “ Santa Rosa de Lima”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia del Huallaga, distrito de Bellavista. El negocio está ubicado en su propia casa situada en el Jirón Bolivar Nº 155, tiene una bodega donde vende abarrotes en general, golosinas y otros productos comestibles de consumo diario. Complementa el negocio con la venta de productos de belleza de diferentes marcas como Avon, Unique y Ebel de los que tiene productos en stock , como también atiende con pedidos. Con el préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará, arroz, azúcar en sacos, leche, aceite, conservas de pescado en cajas, huevos y golosinas, también comprará gran cantidad de productos de belleza aprovechando las ofertas de temporada y así estar abastecida y cumplir con los pedidos de su gran clientela que logro ganar gracias a su buen trato y perseverancia en el trabajo. Ada tiene 58 años, vive con su esposo y sus tres de sus hijos. Ella se siente agradecida al banco comunal por haberle brindado la oportunidad de tener su propio capital y poder desarrollarse como pequeña empresaria.

loans.use: To purchase groceries (sugar, rice, milk, noodles, etc.)

loans.name: Margot

texts.es:
Margot is single-handedly raising her young son due to the terrible loss of her husband not too long ago. She still lives in her parents’ house. As a working mother, Margot relies on her parents, who lovingly look after her child until she comes home. Everyday, she travels throughout her city, looking to increase her sales. For this reason, she has decided to partake in selling dairy products, since she has seen a demand for this while she has been visiting every corner of her city.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

MARGOT, se ha quedado sola a cargo de su pequeño hijo hace poco tiempo debido a la terrible pérdida de su querido esposo. Aún habita la casa de sus padres y para su desenvolvimiento laboral cuenta con el apoyo de sus queridos padres quienes cuidan del pequeño con mucho amor hasta el retorno de su querida madre. Recorre a diario su ciudad en búsqueda de pedidos que le ayuden a incrementar sus ventas, por esta razón ha decidido también incursionar en la venta de productos lácteos ya que ha observado su demanda durante todo este tiempo que lleva recorriendo los rincones de su ciudad.

loans.use: Increase capital to sell dairy products

loans.name: Leang

texts.en: Leang N. is 41 years old and unmarried. Being a single woman at this age is very uncommon in Khmer culture. But she still enjoys an active family life living with her younger sister’s family, including her four nephews. She sells vegetables from a small grocery store outside her home, earning approximately US$5 per day. With her loan she hopes to buy more grocery products to expand her vegetable selling business into a full grocery store.

loans.use: To buy grocery products.

loans.name: Marleney Maruja

texts.es:
Marleney is married, 39 years old, comes from La Libertad and finished her secondary school education. She has 2 children still dependent on her, and they live in Virgen de la Puerta in the city of Trujillo, Perú.

Marleney has a grocery store where she sells sodas, mineral water, etc. She has had this business for more than four years. She started with Manuela Ramos in 2006, receiving her first loan of S./300, which she invested in the purchase of sodas and mineral water. She belongs to the communal bank San Judas Tadeo.

With the loan of S./1500, to be repaid over a period of four months, she will invest in supplies for her store.

She dreams of having a larger store and that additional capital investment will help her to increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Marleny esta casada, tiene 39 años, natural de la Libertad, cursó estudios secundarios completos, tiene 02 hijos dependientes del hogar; vive en la Urbanización Virgen de la Puerta en la cuidad de Trujillo – Perú. La señora Marleny tiene una bodega en la cual vende,,gaseosa, agua mineral, etc. Este negocio lo tiene más de 04 años. Se inició con Manuela Ramos desde el año 2006 concediéndole un primer préstamo de S/.300., lo invertio en la compra de gaseosas, y agua mineral. Pertenece al Banco Comunal San Judas Tadeo”, Con el préstamo de S/. 1500.00 el cual será cancelado en un plazo de 04 meses; lo invertirá en la implementación de la bodega. La señora Maria sueña tener un local mas grande y con mayores inversiones de dinero que le ayude a incrementar sus

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Yem Y., age 49, is married and lives with five of her children in Prey Veng province. She works to support the family as a construction worker, making around $3 each day, and her husband, Som Thy, earns $6 each day, from construction work as well. Two of the children are married and live away from home. Two other children are also employed with different work. 

To make it easier to get to work, and not have to spend money on a motor-taxi, they would like to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. (Mrs. Yem and her husband is pictured together at home.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Marlín Del Socorro

texts.es:
Mrs. Marlín del Socorro N. S. is from the city of Bluefields. She is 32 years old and the single mother of one young son who is in primary school. For more than two years, Mrs. N. has owned a convenience store. Her customers are neighborhood residents and they prefer her store because she offers a variety of products (cereals, juices, soups, soft drinks, natural soft drinks, among other things). Since this is her only business, it's worth noting that the products she offers are in great demand by the population. Mrs. Navarros needs to purchase: 200kg of sugar at $32.00/kg, 2 cans of oil at $46.00/can, 6 boxes of laundry detergent at $12.00/box, 4 large packages of toilet paper at $10.00/package and 1 large package of dishwashing liquid at $8.00/package. With this investment, she will be able to increase her earnings and satisfy customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Marlín del Socorro N. S. es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 32 años de edad, es madre soltera de 1 hijo menor de edad, quien cursa estudios primarios. La Sra. N. es propietaria de una pulpería por más de 2 años, teniendo como clientes a los habitantes de su barrio que la prefieren por ofrecer variedades de productos (granos básicos, jugos, sopas, gaseosas, refrescos naturales, entre otras cosas), siendo este negocio su único ingreso, cabe destacar que los productos que ella oferta no a disminuido su demanda ya que son de alto consumo para la población. La Sra. N. necesita comprar: 2 quintal de arroz a $ 62.00 dólares el quintal, 2 quintales de azúcar a $ 32.00 dólares el quintal, 2 bidones de aceite a $ 46.00 dólares el bidón, 6 cajas de Jabón para lavar ropa a $ 12.00 dólares cada caja, 4 bolsones de papel higiénico a $ 10.00 dólares el bolsón y 1 bolsón de detergente a $ 8.00 dólares el bolsón, con esta inversión podrá aumentar su ganancia y satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, cooking oil, laundry detergent, toilet paper, and dishwashing liquid.

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
María Isabel M. lives in the municipality of Lourdes, along with her husband who is a salaried employee. They have a large family as is the custom in this country. To support his four children, 7 years ago María Isabel started as small store selling homegrown produce and through hard effort and work managed to expand her small business and put up a store selling basic products.

Due to the complicated economic situation in the country, María has been forced to look for alternative ways to make money, putting up a tortilla store to augment the store. Her oldest daughter helps daily in the store and is currently a university student and her studies are paid for by her parents. The M. family is requesting a loan in order to be able to buy more products for the family store that will allow it to develop and grow economically.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

María Isabel M. vive en el municipio D. Lourdes, junto a su esposo, quien es empleado asalariado, mantienen una familia granD., como es costumbre en el país. Para mantener a sus cuatro hijos, María Isabel inicia hace 7 años con una pequeña venta D. verduras casera, mediante esfuerzo y trabajo arduo logro expandir su pequeño negocio y monta una tienda D. productos básicos. Debido a la complicada situación económica nacional, María se ha visto obligada a buscar formas alternativas D. generar ingresos, poniendo una venta D. tortillas para complementar la tienda. Su hija mayor ayuda diariamente en la venta y cursa actualmente sus estudios universitarios, que le son pagados por sus padres. La familia M. solicita un préstamo para así poder comprar más insumos para la tienda familiar, que les permita desarrollarse y crecer tanto económica como integralmente.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies to reinvest in business

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Clemêncio Raimundo

texts.pt:
Clemencio e solteiro de 33 anos de idade nasceu em namaacha um distriro que faz fronteira com a swazilandia, estudou ate a 10ªclasse teve que parar devido ao trabalho que não lhe permitia mais frequentar a escola.

Sai de casa dos seus pais quando a sua irma mais velha e cedida uma casa e pede a ele para cuidar da mesma. Porque ele não trabalhava na altura , a irma dava-lhe uma mesada de 250.00MT por mês. A responsabilidade já era maior e ele quis sempre ser dependente e aranja um emprego no restaurante chiconela onde trabalha durante 3 anos.A sua irma aranja um emprego mas condigno no hotel libombos pois esta e contabilista daquela reparticao, mas para isso ele tinha que ter no minimo a 10ªclasse já concluida, e na altura so tinha a 8 classe. Entao pede o seu patrao para continuar com os estudos  e este recusa alegando que o trabalho que ele fazia não lhe podia permitir estudar, em 2000 ele larga o emprego e volta a estudar, concluida a 10ªclasse comeca a trabalhar em 2003 como recepcionista cargo que exerce ate hoje. E funcionario permanente trabalha das 7h as 19h auferindo mensalmente um valor de 4.000.00MT por mês. Responsabiliza-se pela sua gemea e seus sobrinhos comprando lhes uniforme e  seu respectivo material escolar. Consegue poupar por mês 1.000.00MT pois não tem filhos e vive com a sua namorada.

Este e o segundo emprestimo de clemencio na hluvuku e primeiro com kiva. O primeiro emprestimo de 20.000.00MT ele usou para comprar material de construcao para a sua obra, conseguiu pagar o emprestimo dentro do praso determinado e pede este segundo de 20.000.00MT para concluir com a sua obra. Tem como objectivo ver a sua obra concluida e pedir um novo emprestimo para mobilar a mesma.
texts.en:
Clemencio is single and 33 years old. He was born in Namaacha, in a district on the border of Swaziland. He studied through tenth grade, then had to stop because work did not allow him to continue attending school.

He left his parents’ house when his oldest sister got a house and asked him to take care of it. Because he did not work at that time, his sister gave him a monthly allowance of 250 meticais (MZN). He grew more responsible and always wanted to be independent, so he secured a job at a small restaurant, where he worked for three years. His sister found him a better position at the Libombos Hotel, in the department where she was an accountant. It required, however, an education through at least tenth grade, and he had studied through only eighth grade at that time. So he asked his boss if he could continue his studies, and his boss denied his request, arguing that the job he was doing did not allow him to study. In 2000 Clemencio left that job and resumed his studies. Completing tenth grade, in 2003 he began to work as a receptionist, which he continues today. He is a regular employee, works from 7am to 7pm, and makes 4,000MZN per month. He has taken responsibility for his twin sister and his nephews and nieces, buying them uniforms and their necessary school materials. He manages to save 1,000MZN per month, as he does not have children and lives with his girlfriend.

This is Clemencio’s second loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and his first with Kiva. He used the first loan of 20,000MZN to buy construction materials for his house, and he repaid the loan on time. He requests this second loan of 20,000MZN to finish this work. His goal is to see this building completed and to request a new loan to furnish it.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.es:
Doña Anastasia tiene 47 años D. edad, estudió tercer grado D. primaria, es casada y madre D. 02 hijos (una mujer D. 27 años con  familia y un varón D. 25 años D. edad y soltero). Vive en el Jr. Ica Nº 119, distrito D. Ilave , provincia El Collao, Puno y es una D. las socias fundadoras del Banco Comunal “Maria Parado D. Bellido” en Conduriri.

Con su crédito inicial D. S/.300, compró ropa (mantas, faldas, chompas, etc.). DesD. los 17 años D. edad vendía ropa al por mayor y menor en la ciudad D. Juliaca y a los 19 años formó su hogar y seguía con el negocio D. ropa. Actualmente, con el apoyo D. su esposo, compra y venD. carne D. alpaca a los mayoristas D. Tacna y también venD.  frutas.

Con este crédito D. S/.2,000, el cual será cancelado en 03 cuotas, comprará 15 degollados D. carne D. alpaca a S/.150 cada uno, el cual será comercializado a los mayoristas D. Tacna.

Su meta es cambiar D. negocio e instalar una tienda D. gaseosas y verduras.
texts.en:
Anastasia is a 47-year-old mother of 2 children -- a 27-year-old daughter with a family and a 25-year-old son who is single. She has a graD. 3 education. She lives at number 119 Jr. Ica, in the Ilave district of El Collao province in the city of Puno. She is one of the founding members of the Communal Bank “Maria Parado D. Bellido” in Conduriri. With her initial loan of 300 soles ($1 US = 3 Soles, approx.), she invested in clothing (shawls, skirts, sweaters, etc.). At 17, she was selling clothes retail and wholesale in the city of Juliaca and at 19 she started a family and continued with her clothing business. Currently, with the support of her husband, she buys and sells alpaca meat to wholesalers in Tacna and also sells fruit. With this loan of 2,000 soles ($1 US = 3 Soles, approx.), which will be repaid in 3 installments, she’ll buy 15 alpacas at 150 soles a piece, which she will sell to wholesalers in Tacna. Her objective is to change her business; she’d like to start a store and sell soda pop and fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy alpaca meat.

loans.name: Muth

texts.en: Mrs. Muth E. was born in 1976 and she now lives in Si Sla village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Hang Chhaum, uses a motorbike to transport water for sale. Even though they have different businesses, they still do not have much money to support their family of five young children. Thus, Mrs. Muth E. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Hai

texts.vi:
Chị Trần Thị Hải năm nay 55 tuổi gia đình chị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Năm 2003  chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào buôn bán. Hiện nay cả hai vợ chồng chị đều làm công việc kinh doanh buôn bán thịt lợn. Đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị Hải. 
Vòn vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư cho công việc kinh daonh buôn bán của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. T. Thi Hai is 55 years old. She has 3 children who are all grown. In 2003 she joined TYM fund to borrow money to invest in some sort of business. Currently she and her husband are working together in their business of selling pork. This business is Ms. Hai's main source of incom for her family. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 600 USD to invest in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Derrick

texts.en:
Derrick K. H. is 40 years old. He is married with four children. Currently the first two are in the senior high school the remaining two are still in the junior high school. He owns and operates a grocery shop and pharmaceutical shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk etc. Recently a license was issued to him by the Ghana Pharmaceutical Council. So he has the right to sell drugs. He deems it a big opportunity to expand his business to include other items frequently demanded by customers both at the pharmacy shop and the grocery shop. 

H. has being in this business for the past seven years. He wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams and pharmaceutical drugs, etc., to increase his inventory. He hopes to improve sales to enable him save more for his children’s educations. His picture was taken when we visited him. Derrick would be grateful for your assistance to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc., and pharmaceutical drugs.

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en:
Shuhrat K. is 31 years old. Due to lack of fees for university studies, Shuhrat was only able to finish high school. After finishing school, he learned various skills, including repairing of cars. At the beginning he worked as an assistant and in time he became experienced in repairing cars. Thanks to his abilities he was able to build his own workshop near his house where he provides his services.

Shuhrat is married and has two children. He is doing his best to ensure his children of the best future. Now he feels the lack of tools and spare parts for repairing cars and for that reason he is requesting 700 USD for a term of 11 months. Shuhrat is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve his dreams with this loan.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing tools and spare parts used to repair trucks

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema A. Z. owns a small charcoal and firewood store in the Melinne neighborhood on the island of Zanzibar, Tanzania. She's owned her business for 2 years. She belongs to Tujitegemee group loan (Group code 2003).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. Every day she works at her business from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She is hoping this loan will increase her profits and she can grow her business.  

Rehema is 24 years old, married with a 9 year old child.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Nulu's Group

texts.en:
N. Nulu is the leader of the Wanyange Tusubira group in Jinja. She is a businesswoman with a retail shop, and she also sells used clothes in Jinja. In the shop, she sells sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil and many other things as well as displaying some of her clothes. She also takes some of the stock to the daily markets.

This is her 18th loan with the group and she is happy that the loans have enabled her to buy a sewing machine, a sofa set, a bicycle and a radio. She says that these are things she used to see as less important but now due to the change in her standard of living, she is happy that she is taking this path. Nulu needs a loan to help with buying more goods for her retail shop plus buying more clothes to sell.

loans.use: Buying more goods for the shop and used clothes to sell

loans.name: Kuo Kuo Yuh

texts.en:
S. has been a member of GHAPE since 2007 and this loan will be his second from the organization.  S. is a multifaceted entrepreneur: he owns goats, bee hives for honey, and a photography studio.  This loan will be used to pay for the electricity for his studio and for the labor to upkeep his bee hives and goats.

Because all three of his areas of business are in constant demand, S. is confident his business will succeed, which ultimately helps the development of his small community.  Married, S. will then use the profits of the loan to further his three children's education, to provide any needs for the family and, lastly, to expand his businesses.

S. has faced some challenges in life, like the death of his mother, sickness and lack of education, but remains positive.  He has taken advantage of the training programs at GHAPE, like how to manage a loan, and appreciates the organization for its gradual repayment plan and for the closeness between  borrowers and staff.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Electricity for photo studio, labor for upkeep of bee hives and goats

loans.name: Tuwisana Plus Group

texts.fr: Marthe M. fabrique et livre aux clients des shikwangues (a kind of bread made of cassava flour) qui sont un aliment principal des congolais habitant à Kinshasa. Elle a commencé son commerce en 1998 en s’associant à une femme qui les fabriquait. Elle les vendait en gagnant des commissions. En octobre 1998, Marthe apprit à les fabriquer, acheta 1 sac de manioc avec l’argent gagné des commissions accumulées et commença à developper son propre commerce. L’activité évolua bien de 1999 jusqu’en 2006 quand elle connut le divorce avec son mari. Avec un capital de $320, Marthe décida de travailler avec détermination et une bonne gestion pour réaliser son rêve d’ouvrir un jour une boucherie des chèvres. Avec le crédit obtenu ce mois d’avril, elle a diversifié son activité en achetant 1 carton des cuisses d’oiseaux et 1 carton de viande de dindon à revendre afin d’accroître le revenu de son affaire qui lui génère présentement $60 de bénéfice par semaine. Son capital actuel est de $235. Marthe a 38 ans, divorcée et mère de 9 enfants âgés de 4 à 22 ans dont 5 vivent avec elle et trois vont à école.
texts.en:
Marthe M. makes and delivers to her customers shikwangues (a kind of bread made of cassava flour). It is a principal food for the Congolese in Kinshasa. She started in this business in 1998 while including a woman who used to make it. In October 1998, Marthe learned to make it. She bought a sack of cassava with the money earned from accumulated commissions and started developing her own business. This business improved nicely in 1999 through 2006, when she got divorced. With $320 in capital, Marthe decided to work with determination and good managing in order to realize her dream of opening one day a butcher shop for goats. With the loan she obtained in this month of April, she diversified her business by buying a box of bird thighs and one box of turkey meat to be resold, so as to grow her revenues from her business, which presently generates $60 of profit per week. Her current capital amounts to $235. Marthe is 38 years old, divorced, and the mother of nine children, ages 4 to 22. Five of them live with her, and three attend school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a box of bird thighs and a box of turkey meat to sell for growing her revenues

loans.name: Gbomboya Group

texts.en:
This group is called Gbomboya Group. Its members include Marie Fonah, Magret D., Rosaline K., Kadiatu B. and Mabinty M.. Previous loans from SMT/Kiva have created a significant impact on the lives of these entrepreneurs. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are now requesting a loan of SLL 1,000,000 ($315 US) for each of them to further expand their businesses. 

Marie Fonah (left) is the leader of the group. She was born in Makeni City, in northern Sierra Leone. She is forty years of age, married with five children. Her husband is a teacher and the children are still attending schools. Marie sells “gara lapper” or locally dyed clothes, rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) bananas, coconuts and so on. Marie will invest 80% of this loan into her gara lapper business.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Jerisa

texts.en:
Jerisa J. is a 42-year-old woman married to a peasant who grows crops on the shore of the Nile river in Juba. She is currently in the business of selling fruits like apples, bananas, oranges, and tomatoes at the market of Konyokonyo, which is around the Freedom Square.  She requests a loan in order to purchase more fruits to sell.  She has three children who all go to school and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell.

loans.name: Zuhro

texts.ru: Зухро – женщина 43 лет. Замужем и мать 3-х детей. Занимается продажей канцтоваров и декоративных открыток на втором этаже рынка «Панчшанбе» города Худжанда. Её муж разнорабочий. Когда свободен помогает жене в торговле. У Зухро 2 сына и одна дочь. Зухро закупает товар у фирм – поставщиков. Они привозят товар прямо в её магазин. Поэтому Зухро не так уж трудно приходится в бизнесе. Зухро планирует на новый займ закупить партию декоративных искусственных цветов.
texts.en:
Zuhro is 43 years old, married and has 3 children. She sells office supplies and greeting cards on the second floor of the Panchshanbe market in Khujand. Her husband is a handyman and helps Zuhro with the business in his free time. Zuhro has 2 sons and one daughter. Zuhro buys her merchandise from supplier firms. They deliver the goods right to her store, which makes business easier for Zuhro. She plans to use her new loan to buy a stock of decorative artificial flowers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of decorative artificial flowers

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita J. is 58 years old, a widow, and resides at Poblacion, Leon B. Postigo. She is blessed with seven children who are helping her in generating income for the family.

Conchita’s main line of business is snack and food vending. Her major customers are students and teachers because she sells near the public high school. She has been peddling for three years already.

Conchita is known to be a good member in the cooperative since she joined in July, 2008. She is now applying for her third loan with the purpose of having an additional investment in her business. She is very active in all cooperative activities instituted by the center to which she is affiliated.

Conchita is looking forward to having her loan augment her capital and improve her business status.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her snack and food-vending business

location.town: Sindangan-Poblacion, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga De

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace O. is 53 years old and married with 6 children. She sells sarongs in the market. She hopes for the loan amount to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all her Kiva lenders!

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida I. is a resident of Barangay Madiangat in Quezon Nueva Vizcaya. She manages a hog raising business situated in her backyard. She is married to Romeo and they have been blessed with five children, two boys and three girls. Three of the children are already college graduates and two are still studying.  

Their major source of income is through farming, while hog raising is their family’s alternative source of income. Thus, Loida is asking the amount of PHP 5,000 that she can use as additional capital to support the feed supply of her hogs. Loida wishes the best for her family and she knows that through the support of lenders, she can achieve  her goals. She is also planning to venture into a vegetable vending business for additional income.

loans.use: To support the feed supply for her hogs

loans.name: Be Honest Group

texts.en:
Here are John P. K., Kadie B., Kadija K., Fatmata K., and Abdulai S.. They call their group Be Honest Group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs and farmers in Masorie village, about thirteen miles from Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of Le 500,000 for each for the very first time in order develop their businesses and/or farms. In this way, they will be able to generate sufficient income to look after themselves, their families, and school-going children.

John P. K. is the leader of this group. He is twenty-one years of age. He was born in a village called Benkin but now lives in Masorie village. John is married to a farmer and they have two children who are not yet of school-going age. John sells rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With this loan, he will be able to get five bags of rice and six barters of palm oil (five gallons make a barter). John has been a businessman and a farmer for more than five years now.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina O. is a 57-year-old mother of six. All of her children are now grown. She lives with her husband Leonisio in a small house in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.

Five years ago Josefina built a general store off of their home. An offshoot of her retail business is her sale of cosmetics and apparel through popular direct sales programs such as Personal Collection, Avon, Sarah Lee, etc. Josefina also cooks and sells a popular streetside snack among Filipinos called banana-cue, a caramelized banana on a thin bamboo skewer. She earns at least 9000 PHP a month from these combined business activities.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) credit cooperative for a year now. Now on her third loan cycle, she is requesting a 8000 PHP loan with the cooperative to purchase more cosmetics for her clients. She will also use a portion of the loan to buy bananas in bulk. Josefina has saved much of her earnings and is looking forward to having their house renovated soon.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy wholesale cosmetics and bananas

loans.name: Vincentia

texts.en: Vincentia is married with 6 children and she is 44 years old. She has a shop where she sells provisions and all kinds of wine. She has been in this business since the past 12 years. She hopes for the loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more wine and provisions to sell. She is indeed grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and wine to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita has worked as a vegetable and fruit vendor in their village for almost a year, earning a weekly net income of PHP 250 to 300. She has applied for a loan of PHP 5,000 to use as additional working capital for her business. She works hard for her family, and builds a strong foundation for them to hold on to, no matter what problems may come in their life.

Teresita is married to Jose P., a farmer, and they are blessed with two children namely: Nick - 29 years of age, and Josephine - 20 years of age, both in college. The family lives in Barangay Culing Centro, Cabatuan, Isabela. Their source of income is farming.

Teresita always uses patience in order to perform her tasks, to grow her business and increase her income. She said that "God is the source of everything. When you have a bountiful blessing, you must share with those who are in need."

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is 36 years old and married with two young sons. For the past nine years, she sold clothes in the Muthurwa Market in Nairobi. She is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to purchase new shirts and trousers to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future and add a second boutique so that she can pay the fees to educate her children. She describes herself as hardworking, aggressive, and persistent and says that since she joined Faulu she has learned business principles.


Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To purchase new shirts and trousers

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is sixty years old. She is widowed and has given birth to seven children, all now in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Alice is a trader. She runs a provision store by the roadside in her community. Alice has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase her stock. She wants to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk

loans.name: Noheli

texts.es:
Noheli, de 18 años, es una joven muy alegre y sincera, vive en una casa alquilada y lo que más desea es sobresalir en la vida.

Su negocio es la venta de la hoja de coca, esta actividad le ha sido muy rentable y le ha dado los ingresos necesarios para mantenerse por sí sola. Ella compra la coca al por mayor, ya que le sale más barato, para luego venderla en el pequeño puesto que instala en la puerta de la casa donde vive.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que le da tiempo para dedicarse a sus estudios, lleva 4 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta, ya que le es muy estresante. 
Noheli espera que con el tiempo su negocio crezca y le brinde mejores ingresos económicos.

Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y desea ser muy puntual en el pago de sus cuotas. En su banco comunal es muy querida por sus demás compañeras debido a la alegría que pone en el grupo. Con los quinientos soles solicitados comprará más bolsas de hoja de coca, ya que últimamente está teniendo mayor demanda.
texts.en:
Noheli, 18, is a very happy and sincere young woman. She lives in a rented house, and what she wants the most is to succeed in life. Her business is selling coca leaves. It has been very profitable, and it has given her the necessary income to support herself on her own. She purchases the coca leaves wholesale because it is cheaper this way and then sells it at a small stand in the door of the house where she lives. What she likes most about her job is that it gives her time to dedicate to her studies. She has had this business for 4 years and she thinks the most difficult part is staying all day at her sales stand because it's very stressful for her. Noheli hopes that her business will grow with time and that she will make more income. This is her first loan with Microfinanzas Prisma, and she hopes to be very punctual with her payments. She is very loved at her communal bank by the other members because of the happiness she brings to the group. With the 1500 PEN that she is requesting, she will buy more bags of coca leaves since she has had more demand lately.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her amount of merchandise

loans.name: Rafael Antonio

texts.es: Rafael Antonio tiene 31 años, por lo que su trabajo empieza muy temprano por lo que tiene que buscar el alimento diario de su familia, el tiene 3 hijos de los cuales 2 trabajan de manera independiente y el menor de 16 años está a su cargo por lo que tiene la enfermedad de síndrome de Down por lo que él se encarga de su hijo. Su actividad económica es la pesca artesanal, hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio, Rafael tiene muchos problemas pero no le impiden salir adelante el es un hombre muy trabajador y responsable. El financiamiento que solicito es para capital de trabajo que será destinado para proporcionarle mejora a su bote de pesca y comprar otros equipos. El deseo de él es mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y seguir trabajando furte para su familia.
texts.en:
Rafael Antonio, 31 years old, begins his workday very early as he must search for the daily food for his family. He has 3 children, of whom 2 are working and independent, and the third is in Rafael’s care because he has Down Syndrome.

Rafael has worked as a small-scale fisherman for over 5 years. He has many problems, but that doesn’t stop him from getting ahead, as he is a very hardworking and responsible man.

This loan is for working capital, and will be used for improvements to his fishing boat and to buy other equipment. Rafael’s desire is to better the conditions for his family, and to continue working hard for his family.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: improvements to boat and purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Jhuver

texts.es: Jhuver de 23 años, vive muy feliz con su madre Olga de 53 años, y sus hermanas Tatiana de 16 y Jonathan de 15 años; en su acogedora casa  alquilada que está ubicada en una tranquila zona de la selva central del Perú.Desde hace 4 años se dedica a la venta  de abarrotes , paralelamente también se desempeña en  la agricultura, cultiva café plátanos y cítricos, en ambas actividades recibe la ayuda de su madre  y de sus cuñados, quienes trabajan con esmero  para obtener mayor cantidad de producción que comercializan a buen precio en el mercado mayorista de su ciudad ; Mayra considera que las actividades que realiza son muy rentables porque le  permitieron costear sus estudios secundarios y actualmente vive  sin preocupaciones, por eso para un futuro tiene pensado producir café en mayor  cantidad, asimismo desea ampliar su pequeña bodega y surtirla  con más productos entre  útiles de escritorio, perfumería, confitería.Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y está comprometida a cumplir con los pagos mensuales puntualmente, porque desea obtener otros créditos que le permitan salir adelante y cumplir todas las metas que se ha propuesto en la vida.Tiene pensado  invertir  el dinero del préstamo en la compra de mercadería para su tienda, además de  abono, fertilizantes, insecticidas y fungicidas, también  plantaciones  de café  para obtener una mayor productividad.
texts.en:
Jhuver is 23 years old, she lives very happily with her mother Olga who is 53 years old, and her siblings Tatiana, 16, and Jonathan, 15, in their cozy rented house which is located in a tranquil zone of the central jungle of Peru. For the past 4 years she has been selling general necessity products, and in parallel working in agriculture. She grows coffee, bananas, and citrus fruits. In both activities she helps her mother and her in laws who work with great care to obtain the greatest quantity of product which they then sell at a good price at the wholesale market at their city. Mayra believes that the activities she does are very profitable because they allowed her to pay for her secondary studies and she currently lives without worries. This is why, for the future, she has thought of producing greater quantities of coffee, and at the same time expand her small general store and stock it with more products such as office supplies, perfumes, and sweets. This is her first loan with MFP and she is committed to making her monthly payments in a timely manner, because she wants to obtain further loans that will allow her to get ahead and meet all of the goals she has set for herself in life. She has thought to invest the money of the loan in buying merchandise for her store, and in addition fertilizer, insecticides, fungicides, and also coffee fields to increase her productivity.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprará mercadería para su tienda asi como fertilizantes para sus sembríos

loans.name: Yansy Marlene

texts.es: Yansy Marlene D. E. de 34 años de edad, reside en Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad. Su grupo familiar esta conformado por su esposo y sus tres hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Yansy posee una tienda de productos perecederos y de primera necesidad, así mismo se dedica a hacer y vender tortillas en su casa de habitación, lugar en el cual las personas llegan a comprar sus productos. Yansy solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de productos alimenticios como carne, pollo, verduras de modo que surta la tienda, así mismo comprar maíz para la elaboración de las tortillas. Ella tiene la ilusión de mejorar las ganancias de su negocio, ya que el fin de su esfuerzo es por esto, puesto  que mejores ganancias le permitirán brindarles una mejor vida a sus hijos, en la que cuenten con todo lo necesario para seguir adelante.
texts.en:
Yansy Marlene D. E. is 34 years old and a resident of Lourdes Colón in the department of La Libertad. Her family consists of her husband and their three dependent children, who are full-time students. Yansy manages a store where she sells perishable products and basic necessities. In addition, she prepares and sells tortillas from her home, the place where people come to buy her products.

Yansy is requesting a loan so that she can acquire a large quantity of food products such as meat, chicken, and vegetables in order to restock her store. At the same time, she plans to buy corn for making tortillas. She has plans to improve her business earnings, since that is the main reason behind all of her efforts. The income she generates allows her to provide a better life for her children and give them everything they need to move forward.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mr. Chin N. is a temporary laborer who is always hired by people to do everything they need, including building a house or harvesting mature crops. He has a partner in his wife (she is pictured), who stays at home to raise a few pigs to earn a living. Additionally, the family sometimes grows a rice crop. Chin N. will use his loan to buy an additional hog for his wife to breed and some fertilizer for his rice planting.

loans.use: To buy a hog and fertilizer.

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita D. R. is from Pagadian City. She is 37 years old. Nelita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Nelita owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Nelita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Nelita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Nelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en:
Khodor is a married man and has ten children, four of whom are working and the rest are still going to school. With his big family, Khodor needs to work hard to satisfy his family expenses. He has been working as a farmer, cultivating all sorts of vegetables according to the season. He has been involved in this occupation for the past twenty years. He cooperates with agriculturA. markets in his town to deliver his harvests.

Today, Khodor is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy farming supplies such as seeds and fertilizers to supply his business before the coming new season.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Erik

texts.es: Erick tiene 26 años, es un joven emprendedor con muchos proyectos futuros, está casado con Zaida de 24 años, con quien tiene una hija, y juntos viven en la casa de sus padres. El motor de su vida es su pequeña hija, su mayor motivación, que desde las 5 de la mañana trabaja en sus cultivos de papa, maíz y hortalizas, por lo que también es apoyado por su esposa y algunos operarios, que trabajan removiendo y cuidando dichos cultivos. Parte de esta labor que realiza, lo más dificultoso es tener que regar por las noches, sin tener ningún tiempo de descanso, sin embargo es compensado, con las ganancias que obtiene de la venta de verduras que cosecha, gracias a ello, pudo comprar los muebles para su vivienda y la obtención de otro terreno, para asegurar más ingresos económicos. Es así que Erik y su esposa, planean comprar una casa que tenga un terreno amplio para cultivo e incluso una camioneta para trasladar su producción hacia los mercados de su ciudad. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, por lo que espera mejorar su actividad agrícola y su economía. Por otro lado desea continuar trabajando con su grupo comunal, por ser personas muy puntuales en sus pagos. Con los mil nuevos soles que solicita, piensa comprar varios sacos de abono y una lata de semilla de col.
texts.en:
Erik is 26 years old and is an enterprising young man with many plans for the future. He is married to Zaida, who is 24, and together they have a child. The family lives with Erik's parents in their house. Erik's little daughter is the one who keeps him going, she is his greatest motivation. Beginning at 5 in the morning, Erik works raising potatoes, corn and other vegetables. He is helped by his wife and some other workers who help till the soil and care for the plants. The most difficult part of Erik's work is having to water the fields at night, and having no time to rest. He is compensated, however, by the income that he brings in from the sale of the vegetables he harvests. Thanks to this income he was able to buy furniture for his house and was able to buy another plot of land, in order to gain yet more income. Erik and his wife plan to buy a house with a large amount of land for growing food, and also a truck to take their products to the markets in their city. This is Erik's third loan with MFP [the Kiva field partner], and he hopes to use it to improve his ventures in agriculture and his finances. He also wants to keep working with his communal bank, because the other group members are on time in their payments. With the 1000 Peruvian Soles he is asking for, he will buy many bags of fertilizer and a container of cabbage seeds.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cabbage seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Juana Isabel

texts.es: Juana Isabel Q. D. P., resiD. en El Transito, ubicado en el departamento D. San Miguel, al oriente del país. Vive junto a sus dos hijos D. 9 y 6 años D. edad, D. los cuales el mayor se dedica a estudiar educación básica y el pequeño asiste al kinder. El esposo D. Juana resiD. en los Estados Unidos, donD. trabaja muy duro para poder mandarles remesas cada mes. Juana posee una tortillería la cual esta ubicada en su casa D. habitación y donD. elabora tortillas casa mediodía y tarD., este producto es parte D. la dieta básica D. los salvadoreños por lo que se consume todos los días desD. una a tres veces al día, acompañando cada  tiempo D. comida. Esto es D. mucho beneficio para Juana ya que las personas consumen mucho el producto que ella elabora. Juana solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar maíz por mayor, esto le permitirá obtenerlo a precios más bajos lo cual será D. mucha ayuda para ella, ya que le permitirá percibir mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Juana Isabel Q. D. P. resides in El Transito, which is located in the Department of San Miguel in the eastern part of the country. She lives with her two children, ages 9 and 6. The older child is in elementary school, while the younger one attends kindergarten. Juana’s husband lives in the United States. He works extremely hard and is able to send remittances each month.

Juana has a tortilla shop in her house where she prepares tortillas at noon and in the evening. This product is a staple of the Salvadoran diet and is consumed every day, up to three times a day, since it is usually accompanied with each meal. This is a great benefit to Juana since she already has customers who consume much of what she makes.

She is requesting a loan so that she will have the funds needed to purchase corn in bulk. This will allow her to buy at lower prices, which will be a great help since she will be able to generate better earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn in bulk

loans.name: Shirani

texts.en:
Shirani is a 35-year-old married woman living with her husband and children in the town of Telijjawilla in southern Sri Lanka. She has three sons ages 13, 9 and 3 years old. Her husband works as a driver.  

Shirani has been managing a bakery business for one year. She is doing this business with the help of her sister.  She cooperates well with others, which helps her in the bakery business.

Shirani has requested a 25,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her business. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Juntos Para Triunfar Group

texts.es:
El grupo “Juntos para Triunfar” es integrado por cuatro personas, tres mujeres y un hombre. Los representa doña Remedio H. A., que se dedica a la venta de tacos de asada y campechaneado (carne asada con longaniza), su local lo tiene enfrente de su casa. Doña Natividad, vende frutas y verduras, doña Hermelinda, zapatos de vA. marcas por catálogo que llega a comprar a la ciudad de Villahermosa y don  José del Carmen se dedica  a la venta de plásticos de manera ambulante en su comunidad y las comunidades vecinas.
	
Doña Mello como así la conocen comprará más ingredientes para su venta de tacos como  carne, cebolla, tomate, chile, cilantro, tortilla, refrescos, mesas y sillas. Ella junto con su esposo (aparece en la foto preparando tacos), atiende la taqueria. Ella tiene la confianza que trabajando con esfuerzo y esmero logrará su meta que es tener una taquería  grande en un local establecido en su localidad y que sus hijos puedan estudiar una carrera universitaria.

Este grupo es muy unido de ahí viene el nombre  y sus actividades son diferentes, es un grupo solidario. 

Agradecen el apoyo que le brinda Fundación Realidad y KIVA por ser afortunados de que estén dispuestos ayudarlos para sacar cada uno su pequeño negocio adelante.
texts.en:
The “Juntos para Triunfar” (Together to Succeed) group is made up of four people, three women and one man. They are represented by Remedio H. A. who sells grilled meat tacos and campechaneando (grilled meat with longaniza sausage) from a stand in front of her house. Natividad sells fruits and vegetables; Hermelinda sells various brands of catalogue shoes that she brings from the city of Villahermosa and José del Carmen is a street vendor of assorted plastic items in his and in adjacent communities. Mrs. Mello, as she is known, will use the funds to buy more ingredients for her taco sales like: meat, onion, tomato, chili, cilantro, tortillas, beverages, tables and chairs. She, together with her husband who appears in the photo preparing tacos, tends to their taco stand. She is confident that by working hard and with care she will reach her goal of having a large taco stand in an established local in her community and that her children will be able to study a university program. This is a very unified group, thus their name. Although they have different activities, it is a very united group She is grateful for the support from Fundación Realidad and KIVA; they are fortunate that they are willing to help them each succeed with their small businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For meat, onions, tomatoes, chiles, cilantro, tortillas, beverages, tables, chairs, shoes, fruit, vegetables and asssorted plastic items.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim L. has a medium-sized stall where she raises a lot of female ducks to produce eggs for sale. She has had many years of experience feeding ducks, a skill she learned from her parents. Her husband is a village consultant and also assists her in raising ducks. The couple was married many years ago and they have five children. Two are now married and work in a garment factory, and the remaining three are single and attend school. Raising ducks is providing the family with a stable income, so Kim L. will be using the loan she has requested to buy many more ducks to raise for eggs.

loans.use: To buy female ducks to raise for eggs

loans.name: Khul

texts.en: Mrs. Khul P. is a middle-aged woman whose husband appears in the photo above. Khul P. earns a living by cultivating rice on her own land. She harvests the mature rice both for selling and for her family to eat. Her husband works along the river as a fisherman. Khul P. now has three kids who go to school every day. Khul P. says that this is the business she has always done with great success. She requests a loan to plant a rice crop during the coming rainfall season.

loans.use: To plant a rice crop.

loans.name: Mbaye Mbacke

texts.fr: Monsieur Mbaye Mbacke  Gringue  est  un jeune tailleur de 30 ans qui habite dans la localité de Dara Salam à  Dalifort. Il est père d’un enfant de 2 ans et  est sociétaire  de la caisse depuis 4 ans. Le choix de son activité se justifie par le fait qu’il l’a hérité de son père qui était un grand tailleur très  connu. Il sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu  pour l’achat d’une machine à coudre afin d’améliorer  sa productivité. Par conséquent  son financement pourra lui permettre de faire face à la demande de plus en plus croissante de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Mr. Mbaye Mbacke Gringue, aged 30, is a young tailor who lives in the town of Dara Salam in Dalifort.  He is a father of a 2-year-old child and has been an associate of the branch office for four years.  His choice of business is explained by the fact that he inherited it from his father, who was a great tailor and well-known.  Mr. Gringue is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs for buy a sewing machine in order to improve his productivity.  Consequently, his financing will enable him to cope with the burgeoning demand from his customers. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment

loans.name: Agrifina

texts.en:
Agrifina T. is from the village of Dadda, Tuguegarao City. She is 51 years old. Agrifina is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Agrifina raises crops, primarily planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables, for sale. Agrifina has been engaged in her business for over 26 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Agrifina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Agrifina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Agrifina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Hillary

texts.en:
Hillary K. M. is a thirty-two year old man, is married to Irene K., and they have three children. Hillary's wife Irene is a farmer like her husband but does horticulture, while he does maize and wheat farming. He has been farming for five years now and gets a profit of one hundred and fifty thousand shillings yearly.
